node.title: New CDC reports find "test to stay" policies can help kids stay in school
node.description: Allowing unvaccinated children to remain in school if they test negative for COVID may not be a viable option for every school, the CDC also said.

node.title: Survivors left homeless by storm "don't have many options"
node.description: The storm packed hurricane-force winds and left at least five people dead.

node.title: "Global paralysis" on Ethiopia war allows atrocities to multiply
node.description: Human rights groups warn the "pathetic" stalemate at the U.N. over the war in Ethiopia's Tigray region must be broken as sexual attacks and mass-arrests continue.

node.title: Kellogg's reaches tentative agreement with 1,400 striking workers
node.description: Five-year deal, which includes a $1.10 per hour raise for all employees, could bring end to months-long strike.

node.title: Murder case that hinged on message written in blood is reopened
node.description: Omar Raddad, a gardener convicted of murdering French heiress Ghislaine Marchal in 1994, won his bid to reopen the case.

node.title: Did You See What Big Bird Tweeted?
node.description: Social media is fueling our “parasocial relationships” with TV characters.

node.title: How Bradley Cooper Deceives Cate Blanchett in ‘Nightmare Alley’
node.description: The director Guillermo del Toro narrates a sequence from his film noir.

node.title: Military begins discharging troops who refuse COVID-19 vaccine
node.description: As many as 20,000 unvaccinated forces risk being removed from service for refusing the vaccine.

node.title: Harvard says it won't require SAT or ACT scores through 2026
node.description: The move comes amid a debate over the tests' fairness, as well as the stresses of the ongoing pandemic.

node.title: Details emerge about tornado victims: "He strived to make life better"
node.description: Details about the fathers and mothers, children, friends and siblings who died during the tornado outbreak are still coming into focus.

node.title: Melania Trump launches her own NFT endeavor
node.description: Mrs. Trump is auctioning off NFTs – the first one, a watercolor painting of her eyes titled "Melania's Vision."

node.title: Brazil leader wants names of regulators who okayed COVID jab for kids
node.description: Health agency bosses reported death threats before approving the Pfizer vaccine for young children. Bolsonaro says public should make "their own judgements" on the decisionmakers.

node.title: Kim Potter expected to testify in her trial over Daunte Wright's killing
node.description: She is hoping to persuade jurors to acquit her of manslaughter charges in what she has said was a gun-Taser mixup.

node.title: Holiday Traditions in the Golden State
node.description: An ice-cold plunge in the Pacific, In-N-Out for Christmas dinner and other ways that Californians celebrate the season.

node.title: MMA fighter Elias Theodorou fights to reform cannabis policies in sports
node.description: Elias Theodorou is the first professional athlete in North America publicly known to receive a therapeutic use exemption for cannabis, but he is far from the only one calling for the rules to change.

node.title: Russian court doc mentions Russian troops "stationed" in east Ukraine
node.description: A district court in Russia found a businessman guilty of bribery as he sought to ease his work feeding "military units of the Russian Armed Forces stationed on the territory of" eastern Ukraine.

node.title: Man forced from flight for wearing thong as mask as protest
node.description: The man said he wanted to show the "absurdity" of forcing passengers to wear masks on planes while letting them be removed to eat and drink.

node.title: A closer look at the Nikki Kuhnhausen murder case
node.description: Inside the life of a teenage girl and how her disappearance inspired a movement.

node.title: Murdered teen had dreams of working with her idol Nikki Minaj
node.description: How the death of a young transgender woman inspired a law.

node.title: Video Showing Huge Queue in Florida for COVID Tests Goes Viral as Omicron Hits U.S.
node.description: Florida reported 6,381 COVID-19 cases and 117 deaths on Thursday—the highest daily increase since September.

node.title: At least 22 dead, 16 hospitalized from bootleg alcohol poisoning
node.description: Four suspects have been arrested in connection with the deaths, the Istanbul governor's office said in a statement.

node.title: Omicron Threatens Red America
node.description: In many communities, most adults remain unvaccinated.

node.title: Miss Alaska, Emma Broyles, crowned Miss America
node.description: Broyles claimed the centennial crown and a $100,000 college scholarship. Miss Alabama, Laura Bradford, was the first runner-up.

node.title: Facebook whistleblower fears Meta's plan for the metaverse
node.description: The same content problems that plague social media are likely to be recreated in virtual reality, Frances Haugen said.

node.title: Pollster Robert Cahaly on accuracy in political polling
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, Cahaly discusses his polling methods with Major Garrett and what was behind his polls' accurate predictions in 2016 and 2021.

node.title: : Possible arson blaze kills 19, guts psychiatric clinic in Japan
node.description: A man was seen with a bag leaking liquid that ignited, charring the 4th floor clinic in a building that may only have had one escape route, leaving many people trapped.

node.title: TikTok videos prompt hiked security at schools nationwide
node.description: The videos warn of school shootings and bomb threats. Officials say they're not credible but are erring on the side of caution.

node.title: Claustrophic housing puts Queenstown hospitality sector at risk of Covid-19 outbreak
node.description: There are fears Queenstown's hurting hospitality sector may be brought to a screeching halt if a Covid case occurs among workers.

node.title: What I Will Tell You When You Ask Why My Son Is in Prison
node.description: Alaa is a political prisoner in Egypt because he dared to dream of another world.

node.title: Kim Potter to Testify Her Innocence in Daunte Wright Shooting Trial
node.description: Minnesota cop Kim Potter will take to the stand to try persuade jurors to acquit her of manslaughter charges after the shooting of Daunte Wright.
